results.title: The Cape crusade (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Helen Grasswill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.

results.title: The Canterville ghost
results.brief_description: A delightful animated adaptation of a tale by Oscar Wilde, it tells the story of a ghost who tries to scare the new inhabitants from his house. Instead of being scared, the Otis family find the ghost’s ghoulish games quite entertaining. The ghost becomes quite discouraged until the family’s caring daughter, Virginia, takes the time to discover the reasons for his hauntings.

results.title: The Canterbury tales = I Racconti di Canterbury (E)
results.creator_credit: Productions Artistes Associes, Produzioni Europee Asscoiati, Alberto Grimaldi and Pier Pasolini
results.brief_description: The second part of Pasolini’s “Trilogy of Life” series continues his celebration of pre-modern storytelling and culture. Based on the tales of Chaucer, Pasolini himself plays the author who faithfully scribes the stories told to him by a group of peasants on a pilgrimage to Canterbury. Pasolini’s film manages to evoke the smells, sounds and landscapes of medieval England. Though featuring some of his regular Italian actors (Franco Citti, Laura Betti, Ninetto Davoli), Pasolini also used a large cast comprising British character actors as well as British non-actors (whose non-professional looks and carriage grace the film with an earthy beauty). As the trilogy celebrates a pre-industrial and pre-bourgeois sexuality, “The Canterbury Tales” is full of polymorphous coupling, comic puns, and slapstick about sex, sin and love. Though the film does not shy away from Chaucer’s religious moralism - the Devil and evil are constant presences in this medieval world - Pasolini’s gaze falls far more lovingly on the sweet absurdity and eternal passion of the carnal body. Filmed on location in England, and featuring some of the most stunning architecture of the eleventh and twelfth century as sets, “The Canterbury Tales” is ultimately a joyous and very funny elegy to the faces, bodies and culture of a vanishing peasant past. Music by Ennio Morricone, featuring his selections and arrangements of traditional Medieval odes and ballads. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: The Cancer hunters
results.creator_credit: BBC, WBGH Boston, Andrew Liebman, Robin Brightwell and Paula S. Apsell
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Cracking the code”.
All forms of cancer are caused by faults in the genes. Our new understanding of what causes these faults is leading to revolutionary forms of treatment.

results.title: The Cancer gas
results.creator_credit: Granada International Productions and Alan Segal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Vinyl chloride monomer is a gas used in the making of PVC - one of the most common forms of plastic. Scientists now believe that workmen breathing the fumes of VCM can contract cancer of the liver.

results.title: The Canberra Lake: Springtime sixty-four
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Neil Howe and Visatone (Australia)
results.brief_description: Canberra, the national capital of Australia, has a man-made lake in the centre of the city. We see a working model of the lake, dam, flood-gates, various transport routes and bridges. The lake, designed by Walter Burley Griffin, was opened at the end of 1964. Shows the official opening and the use of the lake for water sports.

results.title: The Canadians
results.brief_description: The film traces Canada’s evolution, and the contributions of people at home and from many lands including Yousuf Karsh, Lester B. Pearson and Dr. Wilder Penfield. It explores the country from coast to coast and to the farthest reaches of the Arctic, bringing to the screen lively impressions of this second largest country in the world.

results.title: The Canadian shield: Saguenay region
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Rene Jodoin and Werner Aellen
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the Saguenay area of Quebvec as seen from a helicopter. From this vantage point, the size and resources - wood, water, arable land and mineral-bearing rock are easy to see. At closer range the film shows the industries and agricultural development of the region.
